title: Oura ring maker raising $875M Series E, bringing valuation to $11B, report says
description: In Brief Posted: 9:39 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025  Image Credits:Oura  		 							 											 									 					 	  Oura Health Oy, the maker of the Oura health and fitness ring, is raising $875 million in a new...
body:
In Brief

Posted:

9:39 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025

Oura Health Oy, the maker of the Oura health and fitness ring, is raising $875 million in a new Series E financing round valuing it around $10.9 billion, according to a new report from Bloomberg.

The round, which is expected to close by the end of the month, would double the companyâ€™s $5 billion valuation from its Series D round announced last December. The report notes that the Series E round could still exceed $900 million.

Oura has sold 5.5 million rings to date, a notable increase from the 2.5 million reported in June 2024. The company is expected to generate more than $1 billion in revenue this year, doubling the $500 million it made in 2024. As for 2026, the company forecasts sales to exceed $1.5 billion.

The company plans to use the new funding to scale production, further expand internationally, and invest in product development.

Bloomberg notes that the companyâ€™s recent growth has been driven by female consumers, retail store sales, purchases made through health savings accounts, and expansion into international markets.

title: EU cyber agency confirms ransomware attack causing airport disruptionsÂ
description: In Brief Posted: 7:05 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025  Image Credits:Rasid Necati Aslim/Anadolu / Getty Images  		 							 											 									 					 	  The airport disruptions across Europe that began over the...
body:
In Brief

Posted:

7:05 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025

The airport disruptions across Europe that began over the weekend were caused by a ransomware attack, according to the European Unionâ€™s cybersecurity agency ENISA on Monday. Â 

â€œENISA is aware of the ongoing disruption of airportsâ€™ operations, which were caused by third-party ransomware incident. At this moment, ENISA cannot share further information regarding the cyberattack,â€ the agency said in an emailed statement to TechCrunch. Â 

The ransomware attack targeted Collins Aerospace, a company that provides among other things check-in systems to several airports, including Berlin, Brussels, and Londonâ€™s Heathrow. The company said it was working with affected airports to restore services, according to Reuters, which first reported ENISAâ€™s statement.Â 

On Saturday, The Guardian reported that Collins Aerospace said that the software targeted was the companyâ€™s passenger processing system called MUSE, which â€œallows multiple airlines to share check-in desks and boarding gate positions at an airport rather than having their own dedicated infrastructure,â€ according to Collins Aerospaceâ€™s official website.Â 

Collins Aerospace, which is owned by defense contractor RTX, did not immediately respond to a request for comment. At this point, itâ€™s unclear who is behind the cyberattack. Â 

The cyberattack has caused disruptions with check-in processes, flight delays, and cancellation since Friday night. Â

title: Automaker giant Stellantis says customersâ€™ personal dataÂ stolen during breach
description: In Brief Posted: 11:29 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025  Image Credits:David Paul Morris / Bloomberg / Getty Images  		 							 											 									 					 	  Stellantis, the car-making giant behind Chrysler,...
body:
In Brief

Posted:

11:29 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025

Stellantis, the car-making giant behind Chrysler, Fiat, Jeep, Dodge, Ram, and other brands, has confirmed a data breach involving customersâ€™ personal information.Â 

In a statement published Sunday, Stellantis said it experienced a breach of a â€œthird-party service providerâ€™s platform that supports our North American customer service operations.â€Â 

The statement said â€œcontact informationâ€ was taken, but Stellantis spokesperson Kaileen Connelly declined to answer TechCrunchâ€™s questions about what specific types of customer data were taken in the breach. Stellantisâ€™ spokesperson also declined to say how many customers it was notifying that their information was taken.

Bleeping Computer reports that Stellantisâ€™ data breach is linked to a hack of its Salesforce database, citing the ShinyHunters hackers who took credit for the breach. Â 

The hackers allegedly stole 18 million customer records from the database. Â 

Stellantis is the latest in a list of hundreds of companies, including Cloudflare, Google, and Proofpoint, among others,Â who had data stolen in a recent breach affecting Salesloft Drift, and a longer list of companies whose data was stolen from their Salesforce instances.

Updated with response from Stellantis.

title: Nvidia plans to invest up to $100B in OpenAI
description: In Brief Posted: 10:24 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025  Image Credits:Akio Kon/Bloomberg / Getty Images  		 							 											 									 					 	  Nvidia announced Monday it plans to invest up to $100 billion in...
body:
In Brief

Posted:

10:24 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025

Nvidia announced Monday it plans to invest up to $100 billion in OpenAI as part of a deal to build out massive data centers for training and running AI models. The companies say they signed a letter of intent to deploy 10 gigawatts â€” enough to power millions of homes â€” worth of Nvidia systems to power OpenAIâ€™s next generation of AI infrastructure.

The deal may help OpenAI as it reduces its reliance on Microsoft, its largest investor and supplier of cloud computing resources. In January, Microsoft announced changes to its partnership with OpenAI, allowing the ChatGPT-maker to build additional AI infrastructure with other partners. Since then, OpenAI has teamed up with various partners on AI data center projects, such as Stargate. Nvidia says the deal will complement existing partnerships OpenAI has, including agreements with Microsoft, Oracle, and SoftBank.

OpenAI says it will work with Nvidia as a â€œpreferred strategic compute and networking partnerâ€ for its AI factory growth. Itâ€™s unclear whether Nvidiaâ€™s investment will be paid out in chips, cloud credits, cash, or otherwise.

title: Stellantis cancels plans for an electrified Jeep Gladiator
description: Image Credits:Stellantis	 	 						1:23 PM PDT Â· September 22, 2025											  			 One year ago, Stellantis announced plans to add an electrified 4xe plug-in hybrid Jeep Gladiator to North America by the end...
body:
1:23 PM PDT Â· September 22, 2025

One year ago, Stellantis announced plans to add an electrified 4xe plug-in hybrid Jeep Gladiator to North America by the end of 2025. The electrified Jeep Gladiator never made it into production.

The automaker will no longer include an electrified Gladiator in its Jeep lineup as it reassesses its product strategy, the company told TechCrunch in an emailed statement. The company cited changing customer preferences as a primary driver of its decision.

â€œThe Jeep Gladiator carries its rugged styling and authentic design into 2026 while adding incredible new content straight from the factory,â€ the statement reads. â€œIt will continue to serve as the industryâ€™s only open-air pickup truck, combining legendary Jeep 4Ã—4 capability with exceptional everyday versatility. As customersâ€™ propulsion preferences for battery-electric trucks continue to evolve, Stellantis is reassessing its product strategy and will no longer include an electrified Gladiator variant in the Jeep lineup. The Jeep brand has already begun reinvesting funding to ensure the long-term growth of the Jeep Gladiator and will introduce even more customer-requested factory features, customization, and additional powertrain options in the near future.â€

The Gladiator is the latest electrified vehicle hopeful to get the axe. Last week, Stellantis said it would no longer develop a battery-electric full-size pickup under its Ram brand, a vehicle that was supposed to be part of the automakerâ€™s U.S. product offensive to sell more thanÂ 25 all-new BEVsÂ by the end of the decade.

Stellantis cited low demand for full-size battery-electric trucks as the primary reason. The automaker will instead pursue an extended-range truck that gets an estimated 690 miles of range through a novel â€” but not unheard of â€” approach of combining a battery with a gas generator.

Topics

Kirsten Korosec is a reporter and editor who has covered the future of transportation from EVs and autonomous vehicles to urban air mobility and in-car tech for more than a decade. She is currently the transportation editor at TechCrunch and co-host of TechCrunchâ€™s Equity podcast. She is also co-founder and co-host of the podcast, â€œThe Autonocast.â€ She previously wrote for Fortune, The Verge, Bloomberg, MIT Technology Review and CBS Interactive.

body:
AsÂ chiefÂ technologyÂ officer (andÂ interimÂ chiefÂ productÂ officer) of Netflix,Â Elizabeth StoneÂ is shaping the future of entertainment for over 300Â millionÂ members worldwide.Â Sheâ€™llÂ join theÂ Disrupt StageÂ this fall for a fireside chat called â€œWhatâ€™s Next for Netflix and for Streaming Itself,â€ part ofÂ TechCrunch Disrupt 2025, happening October 27â€“29 at Moscone West in San Francisco, where 10,000+ startup and VC leaders will gather to shape the future of tech.

Driving innovation at massive scale

Stone will unpack howÂ NetflixÂ is evolving its product and technology strategy â€” from personalized discovery to global growth, from ad-supported tiers to gaming.Â Sheâ€™llÂ also touch on how Netflix adapts to a shifting entertainment landscape that has seen them grow from DVDs to SVOD to now include Live, all while continuing to delight members with design and experience innovations.

A masterclass in consumer experiences

For anyone building at scale, this session is more than just a look inside Netflix â€”Â itâ€™sÂ a roadmap for how to balance innovation, growth, and user obsession. Stoneâ€™s perspective as both CTO and interim CPO makes this a rare chance to learn from one of the industryâ€™s most influential product and technology leaders.

Â Join ElizabethÂ StoneÂ on theÂ Disrupt StageÂ this October and discover how Netflix is rewriting the playbook for streaming and beyond.Â Grab your passÂ before September 26 at 11:59 p.m. PT to get ticket savings of up to $668.

title: eBay to acquire social marketplace platform Tise
description: The company's acquisition of Tise indicates that it's looking to modernize its platform to attract younger shoppers, expand its social commerce tools, and build a stronger presence in the sustainable retail market.
body:
On Monday, eBay announced that itâ€™s acquiring Tise, a social marketplace for secondhand fashion and interior design items. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

The company says the Oslo, Norway-based Tiseâ€™s platform will open the door to a community of Gen Z and millennialÂ customers. Tiseâ€™s community features, such as the ability to follow sellers, like and comment on listings, and receive personalized product recommendations, along with its focus on current inventory, will enhance eBayâ€™s consumer-to-consumer experience.

Tise was the first company to receive an investment from eBay Ventures in 2022.

â€œThis acquisition is a natural next step in our investment in Tise, which will allow us to accelerate Tiseâ€™s strategy and unlock new opportunities for innovation,â€ said Oliver Klinck, VP, GM Global Markets Success and C2C at eBay, in a press release. â€œWith Tiseâ€™s on-trend inventory, loyal community, and social-first approach, weâ€™ll strengthen eBayâ€™s C2C offerings, and more deeply connect with the next generation of enthusiasts.â€

The companyâ€™s acquisition of Tise indicates that itâ€™s looking to modernize its platform to attract younger shoppers, expand its social commerce tools, and build a stronger presence in the sustainable retail market.

The deal is expected to close by the end of the fourth quarter of 2025. Closing is subject to customary conditions.

â€œAt Tise, weâ€™ve always believed that making resale fun, easy and inspiring is key to a more sustainable world,â€ said Eirik FrÃ¸yland Rime, CEO and co-founder of Tise, in a statement. â€œeBay shares our vision, and with their support, we will enhance our community-driven model and enable even more people to participate in the social marketplace.â€

Founded in 2014, Tise has raised $45 million in funding, according to market intelligence platform Tracxn.

Aisha is a consumer news reporter at TechCrunch. Prior to joining the publication in 2021, she was a telecom reporter at MobileSyrup. Aisha holds an honours bachelorâ€™s degree from University of Toronto and a masterâ€™s degree in journalism from Western University.

body:

ğŸ“ October 27â€“29, Moscone West, San Francisco
ğŸŸï¸ Register now â€” Regular Bird savings of up to $668 end September 26 at 11:59 p.m. PT

Why join this conversation on the Builders Stage?

This honest and tactical conversation will cover what really matters when raising your first institutional check â€” from telling a compelling story to building trust without traction. Charles Hudson and Wesley Chan will share the traits they consistently look for in zero-to-one founders, the red flags that raise eyebrows, and the most common mistakes first-time entrepreneurs make when fundraising.

Betting on people before the product

Pre-seed and seed fundraising often happens before thereâ€™s a product, user base, or traction. That means investors are betting on the founder, not the business. And few know how to make that call better than Hudson and Chan. Between them, theyâ€™ve backed hundreds of founders at the earliest stages, before the pitch decks were polished, before there were metrics to show, and often before a single line of code had shipped.

Charles Hudson, managing partner of Precursor Ventures, has invested in more than 400 companies and supported over 450 founders. Heâ€™s built his reputation on backing people with bold ideas and unique perspectives, saying recently: â€œThe earlier you invest, the more important it is to believe in the founderâ€™s narrative and ability to adapt. Itâ€™s not just about solving a problem â€” itâ€™s about whether I believe youâ€™re the one to do it.â€

Wesley Chan, co-founder and managing partner at FPV Ventures, is known for placing bold early bets on category-defining companies. A Google veteran, he helped create Google Analytics and Google Voice before moving into venture, where heâ€™s backed unicorns like Canva, Robinhood, and Plaid. His investing philosophy centers on identifying mission-driven founders who can turn scrappy beginnings into lasting impact.

Actionable insights on raising your first round

description: Ahead of the curve â€” he practically lives there. Before most of the world had even asked ChatGPT its first question, Elad Gil was writing early checks into companies like Perplexity, Character.AI, and Harvey....
body:
Ahead of the curve â€” he practically lives there. Before most of the world had even asked ChatGPT its first question, Elad Gil was writing early checks into companies like Perplexity, Character.AI, and Harvey. Thatâ€™s just a slice of his story. His track record spans seed and Series A investments in over 30 unicorns and involvement with some of the most iconic names in tech, including Stripe, Airbnb, Coinbase, Instacart, Notion, Figma, Flexport, GitLab, and many more.

This October, Gil takes the Disrupt Stage at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 in San Francisco for a one-on-one fireside chat. Heâ€™ll cover his approach to spotting breakout potential early, decoding emerging markets, and whatâ€™s next across AI, crypto, health tech, and enterprise SaaS.

Why this session matters

His bestselling book High Growth Handbook is required reading for startup leaders scaling fast, and his ability to predict market shifts is second to none.

In this conversation, heâ€™ll go deep on early-stage investing, frontier technologies, and what it takes to build a category-defining company â€” from the inside out.

Early insights from a Silicon Valley powerhouse

Join 10,000+ startup and VC leaders October 27â€“29 at Moscone West in San Francisco. From headline-making sessions to hands-on networking, Disrupt is where the future of tech gets built â€” and this fireside with Elad Gil is a rare opportunity to learn from one of Silicon Valleyâ€™s most prolific investors. title: Googleâ€™s Gemini AI is coming to your TV
description: Googleâ€™s AI assistant, Gemini, is coming to your TV. On Monday, the company announced itâ€™s introducing Gemini for Google TV, allowing TV owners to engage in free-flowing, natural language conversations with...
body:
Googleâ€™s AI assistant, Gemini, is coming to your TV. On Monday, the company announced itâ€™s introducing Gemini for Google TV, allowing TV owners to engage in free-flowing, natural language conversations with the AI.

When fully rolled out, this expansion of Gemini to a new platform will bring Googleâ€™s AI to over 300 million active Google TV and other Android TV OS-powered devices.

In terms of TV-related questions, Google suggests its Gemini AI could be used to help people with different interests settle on something to watch that they would both like, or to catch you up on what you missed in a past season of a favorite show. You could also get Gemini to help you find a movie or show when you canâ€™t remember the title or ask about a titleâ€™s reviews to help determine if itâ€™s worth watching.

However, because itâ€™s Gemini, you can ask any other type of question, too, just as you could with the AI chatbot on your smartphone.

For instance, kids and parents could use the AI to get homework help or brainstorm school project ideas, families could use Gemini to plan their next vacation, or individual users could leverage the AI to teach themselves a new skill, among other things.

The company stresses that Geminiâ€™s addition doesnâ€™t mean that you wonâ€™t be able to do the same things you used to be able to do through the (non-AI) Google Assistant integration. Those commands will still work, says Google.

The Gemini rollout to Google TV begins on the TCL QM9K series starting today.

Later in the year, Gemini will arrive on the Google TV Streamer, Walmart onn 4K Pro, 2025 Hisense U7, U8, and UX models, and 2025 TCL QM7K, QM8K, and X11K models. More functionality will be added over time.

Techcrunch event

San Francisco | October 27-29, 2025

title: Oracle promotes twoÂ presidents to co-CEO role
description: Image Credits:David Paul Morris / Bloomberg / Getty Images	 	 						9:45 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025											  			 Oracle is shaking up itsÂ executiveÂ suite asÂ it sets its sights set on AI infrastructure...
body:
9:45 AM PDT Â· September 22, 2025

Oracle is shaking up itsÂ executiveÂ suite asÂ it sets its sights set on AI infrastructure dominance.Â The company announced Monday that it is promotingÂ Clay Magouyrk and Mike SiciliaÂ toÂ co-CEOÂ roles.Â Â 

MagouyrkÂ joined Oracle in 2014 from Amazon Web Services. HeÂ was a founding member ofÂ Oracleâ€™s cloud engineering team and has served as the president of Oracleâ€™s cloud infrastructure business unitÂ for more than a decade.Â Â 

SiciliaÂ has served as the president of Oracleâ€™s industries division sinceÂ June. He heldÂ severalÂ different rolesÂ at the company since heÂ joined throughÂ Oracleâ€™s acquisition of project portfolio managementÂ companyÂ Primavera Systems in 2008.Â Â 

Safra Catz, who hasÂ been Oracleâ€™s CEO sinceÂ 2014,Â is moving into aÂ new role as the executive vice chair of Oracleâ€™s board of directors.Â Â 

â€œToday, Oracle is recognized as the cloud of choice for both AI training and inferencing.Â Iâ€™mÂ very proudÂ of that,â€ Catz said in a statement. â€œOracleâ€™s technology and business have never been stronger. And our breathtaking growth rate points to an even more prosperous future. At this time of strength is the right moment to pass the CEO role to the next generation of capable executives.â€â€¯Â 

While traditionally known as a cloud infrastructure provider, Oracle has recently started to cement its place in the AI infrastructure race as well.Â Earlier this year, the company announced its participation in theÂ $500 billionÂ Stargate Project,Â alongside OpenAI and SoftBank,Â to build data centers and AI infrastructure in the U.S.Â Â 

Earlier this month, it was reported that the company inked aÂ landmarkÂ deal with OpenAIÂ toÂ supply theÂ AI company withÂ $300 billionÂ worth ofÂ compute. On Friday,Â Reuters reported that the company was signing a smaller â€”Â but still sizable â€”Â $20 billionÂ computeÂ dealÂ with Meta.Â Â 

Techcrunch event

San Francisco | October 27-29, 2025

TechCrunch reached out to Oracle for more information on the transition.Â Â 

Topics

title: Blue Origin wins NASA deal to ferry VIPER rover to lunar south pole
description: On Friday, Blue Origin won a major NASA contract to deliver a lunar rover to the moon, a strong vote of confidence in both the Blue Moon lander and the future of human exploration. The contract also means...
body:
On Friday, Blue Origin won a major NASA contract to deliver a lunar rover to the moon, a strong vote of confidence in both the Blue Moon lander and the future of human exploration.

The contract also means that the VIPER rover will finally see the lunar surface after NASA shelved the entire program last year due to delays and cost overruns.

Under the deal, Blue Origin will carry VIPER â€” short for â€œVolatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Roverâ€ â€” on its uncrewed Blue Moon MK1 lander. Separately, NASA has awarded the company a human-rated lander contract under Artemis, but that program is distinct from this mission.

This new award was granted under NASAâ€™s Commercial Lunar Payload Services task order for roughly $190 million. Blue Moon MK1 is targeting a site near the lunar south pole, where scientists suspect there are significant stores of water ice. VIPER will drill down into the surface to test that hypothesis.

The decision closes an uncertain chapter for VIPER. The agency first selected Pittsburgh-based Astrobotic in 2020 to deliver the rover on its Griffin lander, an award initially valued at $199.5 million. After delays on both the rover and lander, NASA canceled VIPER in July 2024, citing ballooning costs, even though much of the hardware was already built.

The move drew criticism from lawmakers and scientists. One month later, NASA issued a request for ideas from U.S. companies to explore ways to put the existing rover to work without adding additional costs to the government.

For Blue Origin, this win is important: This award gives the cargo workhorse lander its first high-profile scientific payload and pins it to a schedule â€” late 2027. It also marks a second major NASA endorsement of the companyâ€™s lunar ambitions after the Human Landing System contract.

Techcrunch event

San Francisco | October 27-29, 2025

About the size of a golf cart, VIPER will spend roughly 100 days on the lunar surface, driving around, prospecting and drilling to map water ice deposits. The rover is equipped with several instruments, including the drill and three spectrometers designed to detect water, hydrogen, and other minerals.

The results are key to NASAâ€™s future science goals and to any long-term human presence on the moon, where extracting resources in-situ â€” rather than hauling them from Earth â€” will be critical. Ice could one day be turned into drinking water, oxygen, and even rocket propellant. Â 

Aria Alamalhodaei covers the space and defense industries at TechCrunch. Previously, she covered the public utilities and the power grid for California Energy Markets. You can also find her work at MITâ€™s Undark Magazine, The Verge, and Discover Magazine. She received an MA in art history from the Courtauld Institute of Art in London. Aria is based in Austin, Texas.

You can contact or verify outreach from Aria by emailing aria.techcrunch@gmail.com or via encrypted message at +1 512-937-3988 on Signal.

title: Unit 221B raises $5M to help track and disrupt todayâ€™s top hacking groups
description: For years, some of the most dangerous hacking threats have come from adversarial nation-state hackers conducting espionage, Russian ransomware gangs targeting critical infrastructure, and governments...
body:
For years, some of the most dangerous hacking threats have come from adversarial nation-state hackers conducting espionage, Russian ransomware gangs targeting critical infrastructure, and governments targeting journalists with spyware that can punch through the security of almost any phone. Â 

But a new phenomenon of mostly English-speaking young adults and teenage hackers has risen to become a top pressing global threat of today, spanning cybercrime, child abuse, and extremism.

By tearing through some of the biggest companies, tech giants, and governments, these young and financially motivated hackers have destroyed networks and extorted hundreds of millions of dollars from wealthy corporate victims. Â 

One of the few companies with eyes on this subculture is Unit 221B, a New Jersey-based security company that has made a name for itself by tracking these hackers and disrupting their operations where others have struggled or outright failed.Â 

Investors have taken notice of the security company. Unit 221B said it raised the $5 million seed round from J2 Ventures, whose general partner Christine Keung said in prepared remarks that the company is â€œthe missing puzzle piece in threat disruption and attribution.â€Â 

Law enforcement has been slow to combat the threat from these â€œadvanced persistent teenagers,â€ who paved the way for some of the worldâ€™s biggest hacks to date, including dozens of corporate giants whose Snowflake cloud accounts were hacked and the ransomware attack on the MGM Resorts. Â 

In some cases, the hackers stole monumental amounts of peopleâ€™s personal data and disrupted companies for lengthy spells that prompted economic warnings for entire nations.Â 

Unit 221B has helped break the law enforcement deadlock in multiple investigations, the companyâ€™s top brass tells TechCrunch, by securing key arrests of high-profile hackers associated with groups like Scattered Spider and the nebulous wider cybercrime community known as The Com. This is in large part thanks to its flagship threat intelligence platform eWitness and its diverse team of hackers, engineers, and forensic specialists.Â 

The company has also helped to recover legal wins and financial losses based on the findings of their investigations. Â 

The $5 million in seed funding will be used to expand and improve its eWitness threat intelligence platform, with the aim of helping law enforcement and government investigators track and arrest malicious hackers faster.Â 

â€œThe problems weâ€™re solving are most acutely how the online threat landscape has evolved â€” youth that are able to go online and cause very high harm, both in the real world and online world, at much speed and scale, that just didnâ€™t exist a few years ago,â€ Unit 221Bâ€™s chief executive May Chen-Contino tells TechCrunch. Â 

â€œWeâ€™re hyper focused on that current problem,â€ said Chen-Contino.Â 

An invite-only software platform, eWitness collects large amounts of threat intelligence â€” information that can be used for tracking malicious threat actors across the web â€” from trusted sources, including police, journalists, and security researchers. The platform aims to make it easier for investigators to identify and track these threats, collect and preserve information for building cases, and hand off intelligence to others for additional work.Â 

The platform is also used by private companies, including the Fortune 500, who use the collected intelligence to track the threat from these groups, such as how often their brand or their industry vertical are targeted or compromised.Â 

Allison Nixon, Unit 221Bâ€™s chief research officer and a leading expert on English-speaking hacking threats, told TechCrunch that The Com is likely â€œgoing to continue to grow in the same trajectory that has been,â€ and that the funding will help the company further its ability to track and help investigators arrest English-speaking threats.Â 

Zack Whittaker is the security editor at TechCrunch. He also authors the weekly cybersecurity newsletter, this week in security.

He can be reached via encrypted message at zackwhittaker.1337 on Signal. You can also contact him by email, or to verify outreach, at zack.whittaker@techcrunch.com.

title: The Oakland Ballers let an AI manage the team. What could go wrong?
description: Thereâ€™s a classic Simpsons episode in which the sly businessman Mr. Burns recruits real Major League Baseball players to join his company softball team in order to win a bet. But when the championship is on...
body:
Thereâ€™s a classic Simpsons episode in which the sly businessman Mr. Burns recruits real Major League Baseball players to join his company softball team in order to win a bet. But when the championship is on the line, Mr. Burns pulls eight-time National League all-star Darryl Strawberry for a substitute, Homer Simpson.

â€œYouâ€™re a left-hander, and so is the pitcher. If I send up a right-handed batter, itâ€™s called playing the percentages,â€ Mr. Burns says to Strawberry. â€œItâ€™s what smart managers do to win ballgames.â€

High-level baseball is very mathematically-driven, with teams hiring dozens of data engineers to study granular statistics that can inform managerial decisions. But like Mr. Burns in that Simpsons episode, itâ€™s tempting to overanalyze baseball statistics to the point of absurdity.

The Oakland Ballers, an independent Pioneer League baseball team, took that concept of â€œplaying the percentagesâ€ to the next level: they let an AI manage the team for a game.

The Ballers were founded by edtech entrepreneur Paul Freedman as a salve to the departure of the beloved Oakland Aâ€™s, the Major League baseball team that owner John Fisher ripped away from local fans in whatâ€™s regarded as one of the most insidious managerial moves in sports history. Though theyâ€™re not a Major League team, the Oakland Ballers â€“ coyly, the Oakland Bâ€™s â€“ established an unprecedented national community of fans who rallied around the team in protest of the Aâ€™s departure. After just two seasons, the Ballers just won Oaklandâ€™s first baseball title since 1989.

â€œThe Oakland Ballers uniquely have the experience of being like a major league team in a minor league market,â€ Freedman told TechCrunch. â€œWe can have creative flexibility. We can play with things and experiment with things way before the MLB or NBA or any of those leagues could do something.â€

Minor league baseball organizations are often called upon to test new technology before it gets implemented in the majors, like challenging calls with instant replay footage or the automated ball-strike system. The Ballers embraced this attitude, especially given Freedmanâ€™s own background in tech, but have added in a dash of whimsy, piloting things that would never actually debut in Major League Baseball.

Techcrunch event

San Francisco | October 27-29, 2025

Last year, this meant partnering with Fan Controlled Sports to let fans make managerial decisions during one late season game. The Ballers ended up losing that game, in part because fans advocated for the funniest possible managerial decisions, rather than the savviest â€“ at one point, the fans called upon a pitcher to pinch hit.

This time around, once the team clinched their postseason berth, the Ballers partnered with the AI company Distillery to commission AI software that could manage a baseball game in real time.

â€œBaseball is the perfect place to do an initial experiment like this, because it is so data-driven, and decisions are made very analytically,â€ Freedman told TechCrunch. â€œYou have the pace to be able to do something literally after every pitch.â€

Distillery trained OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT on over a centuryâ€™s worth of baseball data and analytics, including Ballers games, to approximate what decisions Ballers manager Aaron Miles would make.

â€œWhat the AI did was figure out what our human coach would have done â€“ the ingenuity on strategy and the concepts came from [Miles], and the ability to use the data and recognize patternsâ€¦ is what the AI did throughout the course of the game,â€ Freedman said. â€œSo I think the role of human ingenuity is safe for now, and AI is a tool to be deployed to optimize decisions, but not to make them.â€

The AI-controlled game went smoothly â€“ in fact, the AI made all of the same choices regarding pitching changes, lineup construction, and pinch hitters that Miles would have made. The only time that Miles had to override the AI was to replace the starting catcher with his backup, since he was sick.

Miles took his temporary replacement by AI in stride â€“ perhaps because he knows that his job is not actually in jeopardy. In a video posted to the Ballersâ€™ Instagram, Miles walks to home plate before the game to shake hands with the opposing teamâ€™s manager â€“ only instead of offering his own hand, he extends the tablet running the AI out for a handshake.

But the use of AI struck a nerve for Oakland fans, who see companies like OpenAI â€“ which powered Distilleryâ€™s baseball AI â€“ as enterprises that prioritize â€œwinningâ€ the AI race over shipping products that have been properly tested for safety. For many fans, the AI experiment felt like a betrayal, similar to the kind of corporate greed that pushed three professional sports franchises out of Oakland in five years.

â€œThere goes the Ballers trying to appeal to Bay Area techies instead of baseball fans,â€ one commenter wrote. â€œItâ€™s so over for Oakland.â€

This backlash wasnâ€™t what the Ballers expected, and Freedman does not intend to repeat this AI experiment. But the reaction of the fans models a larger cultural tension in baseball and beyond.

â€œIt never feels good to have your fans be like, â€˜We hate this,â€™â€ Freedman said. â€œBut itâ€™s not a bad thing that thereâ€™s more of a conversation about the pluses and minuses of this new technology now, as opposed to like, a decade later when itâ€™s too late.â€

Amanda Silberling is a senior writer at TechCrunch covering the intersection of technology and culture. She has also written for publications like Polygon, MTV, the Kenyon Review, NPR, and Business Insider. She is the co-host of Wow If True, a podcast about internet culture, with science fiction author Isabel J. Kim. Prior to joining TechCrunch, she worked as a grassroots organizer, museum educator, and film festival coordinator. She holds a B.A. in English from the University of Pennsylvania and served as a Princeton in Asia Fellow in Laos.

Send tips through Signal, an encrypted messaging app, to @amanda.100. For anything else or to verify outreach, email amanda@techcrunch.com.
